title: Koi Population Estimation (Capture-Recapture)
original_question: To estimate the population of koi fish in a campus pond, student volunteers captured 120 koi on Monday morning using professional nets. They applied a non-toxic blue fluorescent dye to the side fins of these fish and released them back into the pond. To ensure data accuracy, volunteers also recorded the average pond depth (3.5m) and the temperature (22°C). On Friday, they returned and conducted a second capture at three different observation points, catching a total of 150 koi. Upon inspection, 30 of these fish were found to have the blue fluorescent markings. Estimate the total number of koi in the pond.

segments.text: To estimate the population of koi fish in a campus pond, student volunteers captured 120 koi on Monday morning.
segments.explanation: This is the initial number of individuals tagged and released (M).

segments.text: They applied a non-toxic blue fluorescent dye to the side fins and released them.
volunteers also recorded the average pond depth (3.5m) and the temperature (22°C).
segments.explanation: Environmental conditions like depth or temperature are distractors and do not enter the population estimation formula.

segments.text: On Friday, they conducted a second capture, catching a total of 150 koi.
segments.explanation: This is the total number of individuals caught in the second session (n).

segments.text: Upon inspection, 30 of these fish were found to have the blue fluorescent markings.
segments.explanation: This represents the number of marked individuals found in the second sample (m).

traps.title: Environmental Distraction
traps.description: Students often feel they must use all numbers provided. However, ecological variables like depth are irrelevant to the Lincoln-Petersen calculation.

solution.content: Initial marked $M = 120$, second sample $n = 150$, and recaptured marked $m = 30$.
The formula is $N = (M \cdot n) / m$. Calculation: $(120 \cdot 150) / 30 = 18000 / 30 = 600$.
The estimated total population of koi in the pond is 600.

title: Stanley Park Squirrel Study Distractors
original_question: Vancouver Parks Board researchers designated a 5-hectare test area in the south side of Stanley Park to estimate the grey squirrel population. On Day 1, they captured and marked 65 squirrels. After a week of rain, they resumed on Wednesday by capturing 200 squirrels randomly across the entire park (approx. 400 hectares). Of these 200 squirrels, 10 had the Day 1 marks, and 5 others appeared weak and sluggish from the previous capture despite having no marks. Calculate the squirrel population estimate for Stanley Park and identify the distractor info.

segments.text: researchers designated a 5-hectare test area... in Stanley Park (approx. 400 hectares).
segments.explanation: Area size is irrelevant if the second sample is representative of the whole population.

segments.text: On Day 1, they captured and marked 65 squirrels.
segments.explanation: Number of tagged individuals in the first session.

segments.text: they resumed on Wednesday by capturing 200 squirrels randomly across the entire park.
segments.explanation: The total size of the second capture session.

segments.text: Of these 200 squirrels, 10 had the Day 1 marks,
and 5 others appeared weak and sluggish from the previous capture.
segments.explanation: Health status is a distractor and does not impact the numerical calculation of N.

traps.title: The Scaling Trap
traps.description: Do not attempt to scale the result by the ratio of 400/5 hectares. The mark-recapture ratio already estimates the total N for the area the squirrels roam.

solution.content: The hectares (5 and 400), the weather (rain), and the physical condition (sluggish) are all distractors.

title: Academic Integrity Randomized Response
original_question: A university conducted a survey on whether students used search apps during online exams. Due to the sensitivity, they used Randomized Response. 1000 students were asked to flip a card: If Red (Hearts/Diamonds), answer truthfully: 'Did you use the app?'. If Black (Spades/Clubs), answer the filler: 'Was your birthday between January and June?'. Out of 1000 responses, 400 were 'Yes'. Records show 50% of students have birthdays in the first half of the year. Calculate the true proportion of cheaters.

segments.text: 1000 students were asked to flip a card.
segments.explanation: The denominator for the observed proportion.
Half the cards are red, so probability of the sensitive question is 0.5.

segments.text: If Black (Spades/Clubs), answer the filler question.
segments.explanation: The other half of students answer the non-sensitive question.
The combined 'Yes' rate from both groups.

segments.text: Records show 50% of students have birthdays in the first half of the year.
segments.explanation: The probability of saying 'Yes' for the filler question.

traps.title: The Half-Truth Trap
traps.description: Students often forget that 'Yes' answers come from two sources. You cannot assume all 400 'Yes' answers refer to cheating.

solution.content: $0.4 = (0.5 \cdot p) + (0.5 \cdot 0.5)$, where $p$ is the true cheating proportion.
The true proportion of students who cheated is 30%.
